messages: cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:56): gotta love encodings
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:58): According to Google, it translates into English as "oavrplr valrlrap ovlarplvkr lkrplouk"
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:59): which in turn is detected as Danish
9dfea2f9bd9114520591dceb20d528a1 (16:05): Wait what
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:12): It's only Document that HTML5 says you should just have a single impl of for HTML, SVG, etc.? Not Element?
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (16:28): about 2 months or so someone wrote a nice article about css terminology (property, value, rule block, selector, etc). anyone knows which one i mean?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:47): aren't there lots of old nice css terminology micro articles?
7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b (16:49): cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb: divya wrote one: http://nimbupani.com/css-vocabulary.html
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (16:49): that's the one :D
7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b (16:50): wow, time flies
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (16:50): well, y'know... waves and ripples... the internet *handwaving*
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:59): if last week's report was Shelley's last, does it mean annevk has returned?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:02): I‚Ä¶ don't think so
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (17:03): who'll step in and write the weekly?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:03): twitter suggests Bolivia

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:18): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, IE9 has massive compatibility lists to solve the browser-sniffing problem, and it seems to work pretty well.  Doubtless it fails on the long tail of sites, but it seems to be enough that compatibility isn't a major liability in practice.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:19): Or at least, I haven't heard anyone say compatibility is a major liability of IE9 in practice.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:19): I haven't used it that much myself.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:19): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Yeah, but just switching to another rendering mode isn't a solution that works well for other browsers, really.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:20): Other browsers don't need such a drastic solution, since they worked pretty similarly to the standards to start with.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:21): They can mostly get by with minor case-by-case hacks plus some evangelism.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:21): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: There are plenty of sites with sniffing like // is IE or Opera, go down IE code-path
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:21): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Esp. those forking on stuff like window.attachEvent
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:21): Yeah, that's because Opera made the mistake of working like IE in a lot of cases instead of Firefox.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:21): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Where Opera breaks if you drop window.attachEvent
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:21): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: It's hard to work like Firefox when Firefox didn't yet exist. :P
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:21): Well, okay.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:21): (And Gecko in general pretty much didn't exist at the time)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:22): I was thinking more recently.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:22): Like, last ten years.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:22): We haven't implemented IE stuff like that in a *long* time.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:22): I tend to agree, but it wasn't clearly the wrong choice at the time
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:22): Ten years ago was when IE was at its peak, and when we implemented a lot of that stuff.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:23): Yeah, at the time it was probably smart to follow IE.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:24): Gecko did too, for that matter, in lots of ways.

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:38): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: FWIW, I'm very glad we don't have compat lists in Gecko. If we had, I'm pretty sure I would have been required to implement HTML5-compliant script loading in addition to the old code path with a compat list switch

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:39): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: but since we don't have that capability to begin with, we just require sites to get their sniffing act together if they want to continue working
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:39): though some sites have more trouble than other getting their act together: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=660282#c6
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (17:42): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: just curious, has Opera started to drop support for various IEisms ?
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (17:42): I remember attempts, at least

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:42): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: How do you deal with major regional sites in countries where you want market-share but where you don't have the marketshare to make them actually fix their behaviour?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:43): 6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf: Some stuff. Other stuff has been tried and then broken more than it fixed.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:43): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: we don't deal as far as I know
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:43): (e.g., the window.attachEvent example above)
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (17:43): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, by having market share ;)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:43): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: except for stuff like keeping heuristic detectors working for Japanese

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:44): There have certainly been cases where we've had to make a choice between aligning with other browsers or keeping major sites working that are likely to not change.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:44): At least not change quickly.

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:45): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Firefox 4 fail big time (crashes) with a Hungarian ad provider, but even that wasn't handled in a special way (i.e. no out-of-cycle release or anything like that)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:46): wonders if there's something wrong with my s key
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:47): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Was that found after release, or simply just considered low enough priority of not block release?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:48): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: found before release. importance seen and cause understood only after release
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:02): Oh yay! CORE-840 fixed, which fixes ~150 CSS 2.1 test suite failures.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:02): (Outline on empty element is not drawn around content)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:03): Yay interop!
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (18:05): https://hacks.mozilla.org/2011/05/aurora-6-is-here/ - i hope they didn't actually implement <event-source>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:05): Isn't that the 150 tests Microsoft submitted that were like outline:blue; outline:red; outline:pretty-much-ever-colour;?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:06): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Well, yes. But that sounds like a lot of the CSS 2.1 test-suite. :P
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:07): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: So when you said "Yay interop!" what you meant is "Yay pointless tests!"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:07): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: Where does it say <event-source>?
7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b (18:08): https://gist.github.com/995177
7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b (18:08): (which is embedded)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:12): Oooh so it does
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:16): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: I don't see anything about <event-source> in the code that landed. What's the Hacks article talking about?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (18:18): prolly ripped an example from wikipedia or something without checking whether it was up to date
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (18:20): anyone know what happened to websocket.onerror?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:21): I thought the IETF had eliminated all error from the websocket spec
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (18:23): I don't put any hope in the IETF fixing something
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:25): the example is gone now
